channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: Stay or Go? For Myanmar’s Latest Wave of Refugees, There’s No Good Choice
item.description: Hundreds of thousands who fled deadly unrest at home confront an uncertain future abroad. Yet for many who remained, conditions are dire.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Biak Tling and Tial Hoi Chin in Farkawn, India, in December with their 18-month-old twins, Bawi Thwang Cung and Bawi Lian Cung. They are among the hundreds of thousands who have fled Myanmar in fear of their lives.

item.title: Russian Court Orders 2nd Ban of a Major Human Rights Group in 2 Days
item.description: Critics of the government said the rulings capped a year of erosion of civil rights and media freedoms in the country.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Police officers outside the Moscow City Court, where a hearing over the closure of Memorial’s Human Rights Center took place on Wednesday.

item.title: Hong Kong Police Raid Stand News and Arrest Staff
item.description: Those arrested, including current and former senior staff members of Stand News, were accused of conspiring to publish seditious material. The news site announced it would shut down immediately.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang

item.title: Covid Live Updates: Case Records Are Shattered Across U.S. and Europe
item.description: Test kits are in high demand in England and Spain as people scramble to determine if they are infected. Delta and Omicron are surging across the U.S., although hospitalizations and deaths remain far below earlier peaks.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: For U.K. Companies Brexit Meant Higher Costs and Endless Forms
item.description: While the worst of the Brexit trade disruptions are over, British exports to the European Union are down and companies are frustrated.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Netherton Foundry, which makes traditionally handcrafted black iron pans and cookware in Shropshire, has seen its sales to the European Union plunge this year.

item.title: Russian Court Orders Liquidation of the Human Rights Group Memorial
item.description: The Supreme Court ruled that Memorial International, which chronicled political repression in Russia, must be liquidated.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Andrew E. Kramer
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Supporters of the human rights group Memorial International outside Russia’s Supreme Court in Moscow on Tuesday.

item.title: Brazil Flooding Kills at Least 20 and Displaces Thousands
item.description: In northeast Brazil, local officials say they have never before seen flooding on this scale. Tens of thousands were forced to flee their homes.
item.dc:creator: Flávia Milhorance
item.media:description: Vitoria Rocha, 81, by the remains of her home in Itambé, in Bahia State, on Tuesday.

item.title: U.S. and Russia Agree to Talks Amid Growing Tensions Over Ukraine
item.description: The Biden administration has not said who will lead the U.S. delegation next month as Russian officials demand commitments from NATO.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: Russian troops near Ukraine this month. The threat of a possible invasion of Ukraine is critical leverage for Moscow.

item.title: An Italian Town Roots for Its Patron Saint of Basketball
item.description: Porretta Terme, in central Italy, is passionate about basketball, and is pressing the Vatican to officially recognize its local saint as Italy’s patron of the sport.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Camilla Ferrari for The New York Times
item.media:description: The church of Madonna del Ponte, or Madonna of the Bridge, in Porretta Terme, Italy, this month.

item.title: Born and Raised in Pakistan, but Living in Legal Limbo
item.description: Pakistan has refused to grant the children of Afghan refugees full rights as citizens. A lack of identification documents limits their livelihoods and puts them at risk of deportation.
item.dc:creator: Zia ur-Rehman and Saiyna Bashir
item.media:description: Madad Ali, a young Afghan who works in software development in Pakistan, says he goes to the beach “to overcome depression.”

item.title: India Cuts Off Foreign Funding of Mother Teresa’s Charity
item.description: The move is part of a tightening of rules on organizations financed by donations from abroad and comes amid a rise in attacks on religious minorities.
item.dc:creator: Karan Deep Singh
item.media:description: Nuns from the Missionaries of Charity praying under a banner of Mother Teresa in Kolkata, India, in August.

item.title: Chile Rewrites Its Constitution, Confronting Climate Change Head On
item.description: Chile has lots of lithium, which is essential to the world’s transition to green energy. But anger over powerful mining interests, a water crisis and inequality has driven Chile to rethink how it defines itself.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta and Marcos Zegers
item.category: Sociedad Quimica y Minera de Chile SA

item.title: Britain’s Crossbow Rules in the Cross Hairs After Windsor Castle Breach
item.description: Britain’s Home Office said it was “considering options to strengthen controls” on the weapons, part of a continuing review, after a man was arrested in castle grounds with one.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: A police officer standing guard at Windsor Castle on Christmas. The queen spent the holiday there.

item.title: Keri Hulme, New Zealand’s First Booker Prize Winner, Dies at 74
item.description: The power Ms. Hulme drew from her Maori heritage shone through in her work, especially in “The Bone People,” which won the literary prize in 1985.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Bernard Weil/Toronto Star, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Keri Hulme’s debut novel, “The Bone People,” was inspired by a series of dreams, took 17 years to write and was rejected by multiple publishers.

item.title: The Year’s Most Read
item.description: The stories you read, clicked and spent the most time with.
item.dc:creator: the staff of The Morning

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Omicron marches on.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A cinema near Leicester Square advertises the need for a covid pass to enter on Tuesday, in London.

item.title: U.S. Coronavirus Cases Set New Records
item.description: As a third year of the pandemic loomed, the seven-day average of U.S. cases topped 267,000 on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Ron DePasquale
item.media:description: Health care workers administered tests on Tuesday in Stamford, Conn. Americans have rushed to get tested as the Omicron variant spreads.

item.title: Will Shortened Isolation Periods Without Testing Spread the Virus?
item.description: Without rapid testing, some experts fear new U.S. guidelines may mean infected people leave isolation while still contagious. The C.D.C. director said masking was a better option.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A traveler arrived at the Los Angeles International Airport on Tuesday, where staff shortages prompted flight cancellations that disrupted holiday travel. “To me, this feels honestly more about economics than about the science,” one health expert said of the C.D.C.’s new guidance.

item.title: Some Infected Quebec Health Care Workers can Continue Working
item.description: All essential workers in the province, including those who work in medicine, will be subject to the new rules.
item.dc:creator: Todd Gregory
item.media:description: Vivien Murphy, 9, received a shot last month at a vaccination clinic in Montreal, the largest city in Quebec.

item.title: Omicron Variant May Help Beat Delta, Study Suggests
item.description: In the lab, antibodies produced during an Omicron infection protected against Delta. If Omicron dominates in the real world, that could lead to a less dire future.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:description: The Africa Health Research Institute in Durban, South Africa, where researchers performed a study of 13 blood samples from people who were vaccinated or had recovered from Covid, and mixed them with different variants.

item.title: C.D.C. Study Suggests Omicron's Incubation Period Is Just 3 Days
item.description: A case study of one infected household observed that it may take as little as three days for people to become contagious, compared with four to six days with earlier versions of the virus.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A computer-generated image of multiple copies of the Omicron variant.

item.title: Hugh Jackman Announces He Has Covid-19
item.description: The show joins other productions that have been suspended, including the Temptations musical “Ain’t Too Proud,” which will close for good on Jan. 16.
item.dc:creator: Laura Zornosa
item.media:description: “The Music Man” will resume performances on Sunday, and Jackman will return to the show on Jan. 6.

item.title: Omicron Prompts New Year’s Eve Cancellations
item.description: No big parties in Paris, Rome, Tokyo and beyond.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: John Taggart for The New York Times
item.media:description: Striking a pose with the 2022 sign in Times Square this month.

item.title: Fears of Omicron’s Rapid Spread Are Tempered by Signs of Milder Illness
item.description: “We can’t stop it,” Israel’s prime minister said of the Omicron variant, but that warning was blunted by early signs of potentially less-severe illness than with earlier coronavirus iterations.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Megan Specia
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A market along the Spree River in Berlin was locked on Monday as Germany put in place new restrictions to slow the spread of the coronavirus.

item.title: Doctors Strike Over Understaffing Disrupts Delhi Hospitals
item.description: While the country’s overall case count remains low, daily infections in the capital region have risen by more than 300 percent over the past two weeks.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: A protest over staffing shortages at state-run hospitals in New Delhi called by a doctors’ association on Tuesday.

item.title: An Australian teenager who partied while positive is charged with ignoring health orders.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang, Saif Hasnat and John Yoon
item.media:description: Waiting in line to take P.C.R. tests in Sydney, Australia, on Tuesday.

item.title: Covid now accounts for a larger share of deaths among white and young Americans.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Disinfecting the room of a Covid-19 patient who died in the pediatric intensive care unit of Children’s Hospital of San Antonio, in August.

item.title: A Giving Guide
item.description: Many people think about charitable giving this time of year. We put together a guide.
item.dc:creator: the staff of The Morning
item.media:credit: Greg Eans/The Messenger-Inquirer, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A volunteer in Central City, Ky. sorts items donated for those affected by the tornados.

item.title: New Year's Eve Parties Are Scaled Back Worldwide
item.description: New York City, London, Tokyo and New Delhi are among the cities where major gatherings have been curtailed or canceled as Omicron spreads.
item.dc:creator: Anna P. Kambhampaty and Alyssa Lukpat
item.media:credit: John Taggart for The New York Times
item.media:description: Striking a pose with the 2022 sign in Times Square this month.

item.title: Germany Wants Its Russian Pipeline. German Allies Aren’t Sure It’s a Good Idea.
item.description: The Nord Stream 2 Russia-to-Germany pipeline could offer plentiful natural gas. But tensions with Vladimir Putin are keeping it out of reach.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Omicron’s effects in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Travelers make their way through Miami International Airport on Monday.

item.title: As Omicron Cases Surge, CDC Shortens Isolation Times for Many Americans
item.description: Hoping to prevent further disruptions to daily life, the C.D.C. reduced the period that certain infected Americans must sequester.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller and Isabella Grullón Paz
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Janice Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lining up for coronavirus tests in Queens, New York, last week.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Israel Collects Data on Fourth Dose
item.description: The studies will be watched by governments around the world.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: Professor Jacov Lavee received a fourth dose of a coronavirus vaccine as part of a trial at Sheba Medical Center in Ramat Gan, Israel, on Monday.

item.title: Poland’s President Says He Will Veto Media Bill Opposed by U.S.
item.description: The measure backed by the nationalist governing coalition sought to limit foreign influence and could have imperiled the license of an American-owned TV station.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: A demonstration in Warsaw on Dec. 19 against the media bill, which sought to restrict foreign influence.

item.title: Carnival Cruise Ship Returns to Miami With 'Small Number' of Covid Cases
item.description: The Carnival Freedom is the latest Florida cruise ship to be disrupted by the coronavirus as the Omicron variant drives up cases in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:description: Outbreaks have been reported aboard several Florida-based cruise ships this month.

item.title: Will Juan Carlos, Spain's Disgraced King, Get a Royal Homecoming?
item.description: In the years since Juan Carlos, Spain’s former king, fled the country to escape corruption investigations, some of the cases have been resolved or dropped. Now Spaniards are weighing whether they want him back.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Casey
item.category: Juan Carlos I, King of Spain
item.media:description: Juan Carlos, Spain’s former king, in 2018 at the Parliament building in Madrid.

item.title: Iraq Confirms Election Gains for Muqtada al-Sadr
item.description: A court certified October’s parliamentary vote that gave Muqtada al-Sadr’s party a plurality of seats, clearing a path for a government to be formed.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Falih Hassan
item.media:description: Followers of Muqtada al-Sadr celebrated in Baghdad in October after initial results of Iraq’s parliamentary elections.

item.title: Pandemic restrictions will limit Desmond Tutu’s funeral to 100 people.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Paying respects to Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu outside St. George’s Cathedral in Cape Town on Monday.

item.title: South Africa Begins a Week of Mourning for Desmond Tutu
item.description: The cleric and anti-apartheid activist’s funeral will be held on Jan. 1 at the cathedral where he served as South Africa’s first Black archbishop.
item.dc:creator: Zanele Mji and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Paying respects to Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu outside St. George’s Cathedral in Cape Town on Monday.

item.title: Reopening schools will be Eric Adams’s first big task as New York mayor.
item.dc:creator: Eliza Shapiro
item.media:credit: Anna Watts for The New York Times
item.media:description: Eric Adams, the incoming mayor, will be faced with the task of safely reopening New York City schools for students and teachers in the new year.

item.title: Israel Study Will Test Effectiveness of 4th Vaccine Dose
item.description: A decision on whether to offer the additional shot, and for whom, is expected within days.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Taking part in a trial, a medical worker received a fourth shot on Monday at Sheba Medical Center, near Tel Aviv.

item.title: Nepal halts Covid vaccinations in children because of a lack of syringes.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma
item.media:description: Administering a Covid-19 vaccine to a child in Kathmandu, Nepal, in November.

item.title: Overlooked Stories
item.description: Today we look at stories from 2021 that didn’t receive as much attention as they deserved.
item.dc:creator: the staff of The Morning

item.title: South Korea approves Pfizer’s coronavirus pill for emergency use.
item.description: It is the first pill approved in the nation to treat symptoms of the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: Manufacturing Pfizer’s Covid treatment, Paxlovid, at a center in Freiburg, Germany.

item.title: Somalia’s President Suspends Prime Minister Over Corruption Allegations
item.description: The premier, Mohamed Hussein Roble, defied the order to step down as tensions continued over long-delayed elections.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mohamed Hussein Roble of Somalia at an election negotiation session in Mogadishu in May.

item.title: Australia Covid Lab Mistakenly Tells Hundreds They Tested Negative
item.description: Human error was to blame for the mix-up amid a high demand for Covid testing, a clinic in Sydney said.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: A drive-through testing clinic at St. Vincent’s Hospital in Sydney, Australia, last week.

item.title: Helping to Reveal a Still-Shuttered World
item.description: Our weekly photo essay series offered readers a glimpse of distant places and cultures that, for a second straight year, remained largely inaccessible.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Hiltner and Phaedra Brown

item.title: As Other Arab States Falter, Saudi Arabia Seeks to Become a Cultural Hub
item.description: While conflicts and crises have battered Arab cultural capitals, Saudi Arabia is hosting film festivals and bankrolling new movies.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Iman Al-Dabbagh for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Red Sea International Film Festival, held this month in Jeddah, was a place to see and be seen.

item.title: Super Typhoon Rai Leaves Miles of Wreckage in Philippines
item.description: Philippine officials warned that residents were going hungry. Many were still in evacuation centers. On a highway, survivors scrawled an appeal for aid.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez and Ezra Acayan
item.media:credit: Ezra Acayan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vehicles overturned by severe flooding brought about by Typhoon Rai in Loboc, Bohol province, Philippines, on Wednesday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Thousands of canceled flights.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Travelers check in at John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York on Sunday.

item.title: Two College Bowl Games Are Canceled Because of Covid Cases
item.description: The Fenway and Military Bowls were scrapped when teams didn’t have enough healthy players to take the field. One team pulled out of the Sun Bowl.
item.dc:creator: Evan Easterling
item.category: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey
item.media:description: Phil Jurkovec, the Boston College quarterback, during a football game against Wake Forest in Boston in November. Boston College did not have enough healthy players to appear in the Military Bowl on Monday.

item.title: No Sailors on Navy Ship Required Hospitalization After Coronavirus Outbreak
item.description: The base hospital at Guantánamo Bay gave vaccine booster doses to the ship to administer to anyone who wants one.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.media:description: Working aboard the U.S.S. Milwaukee on Monday as the ship arrived in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Covid spikes in Africa
item.description: Several countries reintroduce restrictions and mandates.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: Shots administered on Friday at a vaccination center in Nairobi, Kenya.

item.title: The Time Archbishop Tutu Was Searched at the Airport
item.description: A former South Africa bureau chief for The Times recalls telling moments with the anti-apartheid religious leader.
item.dc:creator: Alan Cowell
item.media:description: Desmond Tutu in 1986. Faith was his main weapon against apartheid.

item.title: Even in Retirement, Desmond Tutu Remained South Africa’s Moral Compass
item.description: The Nobel laureate retired from public life over a decade ago, but he continued to advocate social justice, gay rights and environmentalism.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu, who coined the phrase “rainbow nation,” in 2011 at his office in Cape Town.

item.title: Two More Members of the K-Pop Band, BTS, Test Positive for Coronavirus
item.description: RM and Jin discovered they were infected a day after Suga got his diagnosis. All tested positive after returning to South Korea from the United States.
item.dc:creator: Yonette Joseph
item.media:description: The K-pop group BTS in Los Angeles last month. Suga and Jin, second and third from left, and RM, third from right, have tested positive for coronavirus.

item.title: After Chaotic Evacuation, Afghans in the Netherlands Struggle to Find Stability
item.description: Many Afghans evacuated to the Netherlands have been living in tents for months, as they prepare to resettle in a Europe that is wrangling with a heated debate about immigration.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.media:description: Afghan families living in a temporary camp near the eastern town of Nijmegen, in the Netherlands, arrived to register their children at a local school in October.

item.title: Here Are Some of the Many Tributes for Desmond Tutu, a Force for Harmony
item.description: From prominent South African lawmakers to religious figures, many on social media honored Archbishop Tutu as a patriot of peaceful principles who dedicated his life to combating injustice everywhere.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Desmond M. Tutu in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, in 2006.

item.title: Myanmar’s Army Is Accused of Massacring Dozens of Civilians
item.description: At least 35 people were killed and their bodies burned, according to an international aid group and opponents of the military regime.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Karenni Nationalities Defense Force, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The aftermath of the killings in Kayah State, Myanmar, on Friday, according to an ethnic militia whose spokesman took this photograph.

item.title: Training Civilians, Ukraine Nurtures a Resistance in Waiting
item.description: Eastern European nations have drawn a lesson from America’s wars of the last decades: Insurgency works. Ukraine’s training of volunteers has become a factor in the standoff with Russia.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Oksana Parafeniuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: Civilian trainees practicing first aid during a mock military exercise near Kyiv, Ukraine, in December.

item.title: In Congo, Bolivia and Beyond, Where the Green Future Begins
item.description: The Times’s Race to the Future series is focused on the competition for electric-car resources that will shape the 21st century.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner
item.media:credit: Ashley Gilbertson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dionne Searcey, a Times reporter, walked with local residents through an area near Kinsafu in the Democratic Republic of Congo, where a Chinese conglomerate is mining for cobalt.
